article.title: Neither pulled nor pushed: Genetic drift and front wandering uncover a new class of reaction-diffusion waves

choices: The effect of population density on growth rate.
The transition from pulled to pushed waves as growth becomes more cooperative.
The difference between logistic and cooperative growth models.
The effect of noise on the expansion velocity of pulled and pushed waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference in ancestral lineage locations between pulled and pushed waves, as shown in Figure 2?
choices: Ancestral lineages are evenly distributed in both pulled and pushed waves.
Ancestral lineages are concentrated at the leading edge in pulled waves and near the middle of the front in pushed waves.
Ancestral lineages are concentrated near the middle of the front in pulled waves and at the leading edge in pushed waves.
Ancestral lineages cannot be determined for pulled waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 demonstrate about fluctuations in pulled vs. pushed waves?
choices: Fluctuations are similar in strength for both pulled and pushed waves.
Fluctuations are stronger in pushed waves than in pulled waves.
Fluctuations are much stronger in pulled waves than in pushed waves.
Fluctuations only occur in pushed waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What new class of pushed waves does Figure 4 identify based on the analysis of front wandering?
choices: Fully-pulled waves
Semi-pulled waves
Fully-pushed waves
Semi-pushed waves

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 indicate about the loss of genetic diversity in different types of waves?
choices: Genetic diversity is lost at the same rate in all types of waves.
Genetic diversity is lost faster in pulled waves than in any type of pushed waves.
Genetic diversity is lost faster in fully-pushed waves than in semi-pushed waves.
Genetic diversity is maintained in semi-pushed waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What universal metric does Figure 6 illustrate as being critical for determining the transition from semi-pushed to fully-pushed waves?
choices: Population density (N)
Strength of cooperativity (B)
Ratio of expansion velocity to Fisher velocity (v/vf)
Time (t)

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the formulas in (5) describe?
choices: The population density profile of the wave.
The relationship between growth rate and wave velocity.
The strength of demographic fluctuations and genetic drift.
The front diffusion constant (Df) and the rate of diversity loss (Λ) in terms of population density.
The Fisher velocity (vf)
The critical velocity (vcritical) at which the transition from fully-pushed to semi-pushed waves occurs
The growth rate at low densities (r0)
The strength of cooperativity (B)

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the scaling exponents αd and αh represent in Formula (8)?
choices: The rate of change of population density and genetic diversity over time.
The dependence of the front diffusion constant (Df) and rate of diversity loss (Λ) on population density (N).
The relationship between expansion velocity (v) and Fisher velocity (vf).
The critical values of cooperativity (B) for the different wave types.
